nodes.label: Scheduling
Function

Process scheduling is a
critical function of an
operating system that
manages the execution of
multiple processes
competing for the CPU.
System

It is a cornerstone of
modern operating systems,
enabling efficient
resource management and
smooth multitasking in
both single-core and
multi-core environments.
System

When multiple processes
run simultaneously, the
operating system uses
scheduling algorithms to
determine the order in
which processes access
the CPU.
Execution

Common algorithms include
First-Come, First-Served
(FCFS), which executes
processes in the order
they arrive; Shortest Job
First (SJF), which
prioritizes processes
with the shortest
execution time; and Round
Robin, where each process
is allocated a fixed time
slice (quantum) before
switching to the next
process.
Process

Priority scheduling
assigns priority levels
to processes, ensuring
higher-priority tasks are
executed first.
Cpu

Its primary goal is to
maximize CPU utilization,
ensure fairness, and
minimize waiting and
response times.
Algorithm

These algorithms balance
efficiency and fairness,
preventing any single
process from monopolizing
the CPU.

original.original_text: Process scheduling is a critical function of an operating system that manages the execution of multiple processes competing for the CPU. Its primary goal is to maximize CPU utilization, ensure fairness, and minimize waiting and response times. When multiple processes run simultaneously, the operating system uses scheduling algorithms to determine the order in which processes access the CPU. Common algorithms include First-Come, First-Served (FCFS), which executes processes in the order they arrive; Shortest Job First (SJF), which prioritizes processes with the shortest execution time; and Round Robin, where each process is allocated a fixed time slice (quantum) before switching to the next process. Priority scheduling assigns priority levels to processes, ensuring higher-priority tasks are executed first. These algorithms balance efficiency and fairness, preventing any single process from monopolizing the CPU. Scheduling also handles multitasking, allowing users to run multiple applications seamlessly. By optimizing process execution, scheduling enhances system performance, reduces idle time, and ensures a responsive computing experience. It is a cornerstone of modern operating systems, enabling efficient resource management and smooth multitasking in both single-core and multi-core environments.

original.original_text:
Photosynthesis is the process by which green plants, algae, and some bacteria convert sunlight into energy. It is one of the most important processes on Earth because it produces oxygen and provides the energy that nearly all living organisms rely on. Without photosynthesis, life as we know it would not exist.

During photosynthesis, plants take in carbon dioxide from the air and water from the soil. Using sunlight as an energy source, they transform these raw materials into glucose, a type of sugar that serves as food for the plant, and oxygen, which is released into the atmosphere. This process happens in the chloroplasts of plant cells, which contain a green pigment called chlorophyll. Chlorophyll absorbs sunlight and gives plants their green color.

Photosynthesis can be divided into two main stages. The first stage, called the light-dependent reactions, uses sunlight to create energy-rich molecules. The second stage, known as the Calvin cycle, uses these molecules to convert carbon dioxide into glucose. This glucose not only fuels the plant’s growth but also serves as a vital energy source for other organisms that eat plants. In this way, photosynthesis supports the entire food chain and maintains the balance of oxygen and carbon dioxide in the atmosphere.

original.original_text:
Photosynthesis is the process by which green plants, algae, and some bacteria convert sunlight into energy. It is one of the most important processes on Earth because it produces oxygen and provides the energy that nearly all living organisms rely on. Without photosynthesis, life as we know it would not exist.

During photosynthesis, plants take in carbon dioxide from the air and water from the soil. Using sunlight as an energy source, they transform these raw materials into glucose, a type of sugar that serves as food for the plant, and oxygen, which is released into the atmosphere. This process happens in the chloroplasts of plant cells, which contain a green pigment called chlorophyll. Chlorophyll absorbs sunlight and gives plants their green color.

Photosynthesis can be divided into two main stages. The first stage, called the light-dependent reactions, uses sunlight to create energy-rich molecules. The second stage, known as the Calvin cycle, uses these molecules to convert carbon dioxide into glucose. This glucose not only fuels the plant’s growth but also serves as a vital energy source for other organisms that eat plants. In this way, photosynthesis supports the entire food chain and maintains the balance of oxygen and carbon dioxide in the atmosphere.

Scheduling
Function

Process scheduling is a
critical function of an
operating system that
manages the execution of
multiple processes
competing for the CPU.
System

It is a cornerstone of
modern operating systems,
enabling efficient
resource management and
smooth multitasking in
both single-core and
multi-core environments.
System

When multiple processes
run simultaneously, the
operating system uses
scheduling algorithms to
determine the order in
which processes access
the CPU.
Execution

Common algorithms include
First-Come, First-Served
(FCFS), which executes
processes in the order
they arrive; Shortest Job
First (SJF), which
prioritizes processes
with the shortest
execution time; and Round
Robin, where each process
is allocated a fixed time
slice (quantum) before
switching to the next
process.
Process

Priority scheduling
assigns priority levels
to processes, ensuring
higher-priority tasks are
executed first.
Cpu

Its primary goal is to
maximize CPU utilization,
ensure fairness, and
minimize waiting and
response times.
Algorithm

These algorithms balance
efficiency and fairness,
preventing any single
process from monopolizing
the CPU.

original.original_text: Process scheduling is a critical function of an operating system that manages the execution of multiple processes competing for the CPU. Its primary goal is to maximize CPU utilization, ensure fairness, and minimize waiting and response times. When multiple processes run simultaneously, the operating system uses scheduling algorithms to determine the order in which processes access the CPU. Common algorithms include First-Come, First-Served (FCFS), which executes processes in the order they arrive; Shortest Job First (SJF), which prioritizes processes with the shortest execution time; and Round Robin, where each process is allocated a fixed time slice (quantum) before switching to the next process. Priority scheduling assigns priority levels to processes, ensuring higher-priority tasks are executed first. These algorithms balance efficiency and fairness, preventing any single process from monopolizing the CPU. Scheduling also handles multitasking, allowing users to run multiple applications seamlessly. By optimizing process execution, scheduling enhances system performance, reduces idle time, and ensures a responsive computing experience. It is a cornerstone of modern operating systems, enabling efficient resource management and smooth multitasking in both single-core and multi-core environments.

original.original_text:
Photosynthesis is the process by which green plants, algae, and some bacteria convert sunlight into energy. It is one of the most important processes on Earth because it produces oxygen and provides the energy that nearly all living organisms rely on. Without photosynthesis, life as we know it would not exist.

During photosynthesis, plants take in carbon dioxide from the air and water from the soil. Using sunlight as an energy source, they transform these raw materials into glucose, a type of sugar that serves as food for the plant, and oxygen, which is released into the atmosphere. This process happens in the chloroplasts of plant cells, which contain a green pigment called chlorophyll. Chlorophyll absorbs sunlight and gives plants their green color.

Photosynthesis can be divided into two main stages. The first stage, called the light-dependent reactions, uses sunlight to create energy-rich molecules. The second stage, known as the Calvin cycle, uses these molecules to convert carbon dioxide into glucose. This glucose not only fuels the plant’s growth but also serves as a vital energy source for other organisms that eat plants. In this way, photosynthesis supports the entire food chain and maintains the balance of oxygen and carbon dioxide in the atmosphere.

Process scheduling

Process scheduling is a
critical function of an
operating system that
manages the execution of
multiple processes
competing for the CPU.
The cpu

When multiple processes
run simultaneously, the
operating system uses
scheduling algorithms to
determine the order in
which processes access
the CPU.
The order

Common algorithms include
First-Come, First-Served
(FCFS), which executes
processes in the order
they arrive; Shortest Job
First (SJF), which
prioritizes processes
with the shortest
execution time; and Round
Robin, where each process
is allocated a fixed time
slice (quantum) before
switching to the next
process.
Priority levels

Priority scheduling
assigns priority levels
to processes, ensuring
higher-priority tasks are
executed first.
Process execution

By optimizing process
execution, scheduling
enhances system
performance, reduces idle
time, and ensures a
responsive computing
experience.
Cpu utilization

Its primary goal is to
maximize CPU utilization,
ensure fairness, and
minimize waiting and
response times.

original.original_text: Process scheduling is a critical function of an operating system that manages the execution of multiple processes competing for the CPU. Its primary goal is to maximize CPU utilization, ensure fairness, and minimize waiting and response times. When multiple processes run simultaneously, the operating system uses scheduling algorithms to determine the order in which processes access the CPU. Common algorithms include First-Come, First-Served (FCFS), which executes processes in the order they arrive; Shortest Job First (SJF), which prioritizes processes with the shortest execution time; and Round Robin, where each process is allocated a fixed time slice (quantum) before switching to the next process. Priority scheduling assigns priority levels to processes, ensuring higher-priority tasks are executed first. These algorithms balance efficiency and fairness, preventing any single process from monopolizing the CPU. Scheduling also handles multitasking, allowing users to run multiple applications seamlessly. By optimizing process execution, scheduling enhances system performance, reduces idle time, and ensures a responsive computing experience. It is a cornerstone of modern operating systems, enabling efficient resource management and smooth multitasking in both single-core and multi-core environments.

plants.

This process happens in
the chloroplasts of plant
cells, which contain a
green pigment called
chlorophyll.
Energy

It is one of the most
important processes on
Earth because it produces
oxygen and provides the
energy that nearly all
living organisms rely on.
Sunlight

Chlorophyll absorbs
sunlight and gives plants
their green color.
Life

Without photosynthesis,
life as we know it would
not exist.
Carbon dioxide

During photosynthesis,
plants take in carbon
dioxide from the air and
water from the soil.
This way

photosynthesis supports
the entire food chain and
maintains the balance of
oxygen and carbon dioxide
in the atmosphere.

Process scheduling

Process scheduling is a
critical function of an
operating system that
manages the execution of
multiple processes
competing for the CPU.
The cpu

When multiple processes
run simultaneously, the
operating system uses
scheduling algorithms to
determine the order in
which processes access
the CPU.
The order

Common algorithms include
First-Come, First-Served
(FCFS), which executes
processes in the order
they arrive; Shortest Job
First (SJF), which
prioritizes processes
with the shortest
execution time; and Round
Robin, where each process
is allocated a fixed time
slice (quantum) before
switching to the next
process.
Priority levels

Priority scheduling
assigns priority levels
to processes, ensuring
higher-priority tasks are
executed first.
Process execution

By optimizing process
execution, scheduling
enhances system
performance, reduces idle
time, and ensures a
responsive computing
experience.
Cpu utilization

Its primary goal is to
maximize CPU utilization,
ensure fairness, and
minimize waiting and
response times.

original.original_text: Process scheduling is a critical function of an operating system that manages the execution of multiple processes competing for the CPU. Its primary goal is to maximize CPU utilization, ensure fairness, and minimize waiting and response times. When multiple processes run simultaneously, the operating system uses scheduling algorithms to determine the order in which processes access the CPU. Common algorithms include First-Come, First-Served (FCFS), which executes processes in the order they arrive; Shortest Job First (SJF), which prioritizes processes with the shortest execution time; and Round Robin, where each process is allocated a fixed time slice (quantum) before switching to the next process. Priority scheduling assigns priority levels to processes, ensuring higher-priority tasks are executed first. These algorithms balance efficiency and fairness, preventing any single process from monopolizing the CPU. Scheduling also handles multitasking, allowing users to run multiple applications seamlessly. By optimizing process execution, scheduling enhances system performance, reduces idle time, and ensures a responsive computing experience. It is a cornerstone of modern operating systems, enabling efficient resource management and smooth multitasking in both single-core and multi-core environments.

Scheduling also handles multitasking, allowing users to run multiple applications seamlessly. By optimizing process execution, scheduling enhances system performance, reduces idle time, and ensures a responsive computing experience. It is a cornerstone of modern operating systems, enabling efficient resource management and smooth multitasking in both single-core and multi-core environments.

original.original_text: Process scheduling is a critical function of an operating system that manages the execution of multiple processes competing for the CPU. Its primary goal is to maximize CPU utilization, ensure fairness, and minimize waiting and response times. When multiple processes run simultaneously, the operating system uses scheduling algorithms to determine the order in which processes access the CPU. Common algorithms include First-Come, First-Served (FCFS), which executes processes in the order they arrive; Shortest Job First (SJF), which prioritizes processes with the shortest execution time; and Round Robin, where each process is allocated a fixed time slice (quantum) before switching to the next process. Priority scheduling assigns priority levels to processes, ensuring higher-priority tasks are executed first. These algorithms balance efficiency and fairness, preventing any single process from monopolizing the CPU. Scheduling also handles multitasking, allowing users to run multiple applications seamlessly. By optimizing process execution, scheduling enhances system performance, reduces idle time, and ensures a responsive computing experience. It is a cornerstone of modern operating systems, enabling efficient resource management and smooth multitasking in both single-core and multi-core environments.

assigns priority levels
to processes, ensuring

executed first.

execution, scheduling
enhances system
performance, reduces idle
time, and ensures a
responsive computing
experience.
Cpu utilization

Its primary goal is to
maximize CPU utilization,
ensure fairness, and
minimize waiting and
response times.
Scheduling
Process scheduling

Process scheduling is a
critical function of an
operating system that
manages the execution of
multiple processes
competing for the CPU.
The cpu

When multiple processes
run simultaneously, the
operating system uses
scheduling algorithms to
determine the order in
which processes access
the CPU.
The order

Common algorithms include
First-Come, First-Served
(FCFS), which executes
processes in the order
they arrive; Shortest Job
First (SJF), which
prioritizes processes
with the shortest
execution time; and Round
Robin, where each process
is allocated a fixed time
slice (quantum) before
switching to the next
process.

Photosynthesis
The process

Photosynthesis is the
process by which green
plants, algae, and some
bacteria convert sunlight
into energy.
Sunlight

Using sunlight as an
energy source, they
transform these raw
materials into glucose, a
type of sugar that serves
as food for the plant,
and oxygen, which is
released into the
atmosphere.
Energy

The first stage, called
the light-dependent
reactions, uses sunlight
to create energy-rich
molecules.
Glucose

The second stage, known
as the Calvin cycle, uses
these molecules to
convert carbon dioxide
into glucose.
The plant

This glucose not only
fuels the plant’s growth
but also serves as a
vital energy source for
other organisms that eat
plants.
Chlorophyll

This process happens in
the chloroplasts of plant
cells, which contain a
green pigment called
chlorophyll.
Energy

It is one of the most
important processes on
Earth because it produces
oxygen and provides the
energy that nearly all
living organisms rely on.
Sunlight

Chlorophyll absorbs
sunlight and gives plants
their green color.
Life

Without photosynthesis,
life as we know it would
not exist.
Carbon dioxide

During photosynthesis,
plants take in carbon
dioxide from the air and
water from the soil.
This way

In this way,
photosynthesis supports
the entire food chain and
maintains the balance of
oxygen and carbon dioxide
in the atmosphere.

Photosynthesis is the process by
which green plants, algae, and
some bacteria convert sunlight
into energy

It is one of the most important
processes on Earth because it
produces oxygen and provides the
energy that nearly all living
organisms rely on

Without photosynthesis, life as
we know it would not exist

During photosynthesis, plants
take in carbon dioxide from the
air and water from the soil

Using sunlight as an energy
source, they transform these raw
materials into glucose, a type
of sugar that serves as food for
the plant, and oxygen, which is
released into the atmosphere

This process happens in the
chloroplasts of plant cells,
which contain a green pigment
called chlorophyll

Chlorophyll absorbs sunlight and
gives plants their green color

original.summary: Photosynthesis is the process by which green plants, algae, and some bacteria convert sunlight into energy. Using sunlight as an energy source, they transform these raw materials into glucose, a type of sugar that serves as food for the plant, and oxygen, which is released into the atmosphere. This glucose not only fuels the plant’s growth but also serves as a vital energy source for other organisms that eat plants.

original.summary: Photosynthesis is the process by which green plants, algae, and some bacteria convert sunlight into energy. Using sunlight as an energy source, they transform these raw materials into glucose, a type of sugar that serves as food for the plant, and oxygen, which is released into the atmosphere. This glucose not only fuels the plant’s growth but also serves as a vital energy source for other organisms that eat plants.

Using sunlight as an

he music of the Indian
subcontinent is usually
divided into two major
traditions of classical
music: Hindustani music
of North India and
Karnatak music of South
India, although many
regions of India also
have their own musical
traditions that are
independent of these.
South india

One of the main
differences between North
Indian and South Indian
music is the increased
influence of Persian
music and musical
instruments in the north.
India

From the late twelfth
century through the rise
of British occupation,
North India was under the
control of a Muslim
minority that was never
able to extend its sphere
of influence to South
India.
He

Both Hindustani and
Karnatak music use the
system of ragas—sets of
pitches and small motives
for melody
construction—and tala for
rhythm.
That

Legend has it that the
tabla was formed by
splitting a pakhavaj drum
in half, with the larger
side becoming the bayan
and the smaller side the
dahini.
These

Within these rhythmic
structures, musicians (

patterns building off the

Algorithm
Each step

A **greedy algorithm** is
a problem-solving
approach that makes the
**locally optimal choice
at each step** with the
hope of finding a
**global optimum**.
The problem

For a greedy algorithm to
guarantee the best
solution, the problem
must have two properties:
**greedy choice
property** (a globally
optimal solution can be
arrived at by making a
series of locally optimal
choices) and **optimal
substructure** (an
optimal solution to the
problem contains optimal
solutions to its
subproblems).
Greedy algorithms

Common problems solved by
greedy algorithms include
**activity selection**,
**fractional knapsack**,
**Huffman coding**,
**Prim’s** and
**Kruskal’s algorithms**
for minimum spanning
trees, and **Dijkstra’s
algorithm** for shortest
paths (with non-negative
weights).
Speed

The main advantage of
greedy algorithms is
their **speed and
simplicity**, often
having lower time
complexity than dynamic
programming solutions.
That

It builds up a solution
piece by piece, always
choosing the next step
that offers the most
immediate benefit.

Therefore, greedy
algorithms are best
suited for problems where
they are **provably
optimal**.

Each step

A **greedy algorithm** is
a problem-solving
approach that makes the
**locally optimal choice
at each step** with the
hope of finding a
**global optimum**.
The problem

For a greedy algorithm to
guarantee the best
solution, the problem
must have two properties:
**greedy choice
property** (a globally
optimal solution can be
arrived at by making a
series of locally optimal
choices) and **optimal
substructure** (an
optimal solution to the
problem contains optimal
solutions to its
subproblems).
Greedy algorithms

Common problems solved by
greedy algorithms include
**activity selection**,
**fractional knapsack**,
**Huffman coding**,
**Prim’s** and
**Kruskal’s algorithms**
for minimum spanning
trees, and **Dijkstra’s
algorithm** for shortest
paths (with non-negative
weights).
Speed

The main advantage of
greedy algorithms is
their **speed and
simplicity**, often
having lower time
complexity than dynamic
programming solutions.

method used in computer
science to solve

The working

algorithm involves

state, making the locally

process until the
solution is complete.

If the problem does not

or suboptimal.

Photosynthesis
The process

Photosynthesis is the
process by which green
plants, algae, and some
bacteria convert sunlight
into energy.
Sunlight

Using sunlight as an
energy source, they
transform these raw
materials into glucose, a
type of sugar that serves
as food for the plant,
and oxygen, which is
released into the
atmosphere.
Energy

The first stage, called
the light-dependent
reactions, uses sunlight
to create energy-rich
molecules.
Glucose

The second stage, known
as the Calvin cycle, uses
these molecules to
convert carbon dioxide
into glucose.
The plant

This glucose not only
fuels the plant’s growth
but also serves as a
vital energy source for
other organisms that eat
plants.
Chlorophyll

This process happens in
the chloroplasts of plant
cells, which contain a
green pigment called
chlorophyll.
Energy

It is one of the most
important processes on
Earth because it produces
oxygen and provides the
energy that nearly all
living organisms rely on.
Sunlight

Chlorophyll absorbs
sunlight and gives plants
their green color.
Life

Without photosynthesis,
life as we know it would
not exist.
Carbon dioxide

During photosynthesis,
plants take in carbon
dioxide from the air and
water from the soil.
This way

In this way,
photosynthesis supports
the entire food chain and
maintains the balance of
oxygen and carbon dioxide
in the atmosphere.

A greedy algorithm is a method
used in computer science to
solve optimization problems by
making a sequence of choices,
each of which looks best at the
moment

The core idea is to choose the
option that gives the most
immediate benefit without
worrying about future
consequences

This method is based on two key
principles: the greedy choice
property and optimal
substructure

The working of a greedy
algorithm involves starting from
an initial state, making the
locally optimal choice at each
step, and continuing this
process until the solution is
complete

It does not revise previous
decisions, which makes it faster
and simpler to implement

Greedy algorithms offer several
advantages

They are generally easy to code,
require less memory, and are
efficient in terms of time
